newsitem.title: BAHRAIN: Bahrain court jails two accused Qatari spies.
newsitem.headline: Bahrain court jails two accused Qatari spies.

text.p: Bahrain's State Security Court on Wednesday found a Qatari man and woman guilty of spying for Doha and sentenced them to three years in prison, a government official said.
"Two Qataris arrested for spying were sentenced to three years in prison each and were fined 1,000 dinars ($2,650) each by the court on Wednesday," the official told Reuters.
The court's ruling cannot be appealed.
A statement by Qatar's interior ministry described the ruling as "futile" and demanded the release of its two nationals.

The trial of Fahad Hamad Abdullah al-Baker and Salwa Jassim Mohammed Fakhri began on December 4. Manama has said the two confessed to the charges before an investigating judge. Qatar denies the two were spies.
The official said the time already spent in custody would count towards the Qataris' overall prison terms.
It was unclear when the two were arrested, but a source close to the court said they were detained about five months ago.

"Qatar regrets and denounces the ruling passed today following closed door and secretive consultations by the State Security Court," said a Qatari interior minstry official in a statement carried by the state-run Qatar News Agency (QNA).
The official dismissed the ruling as "futile as it had been passed under oppression and coercion and in violation of laws and international norms".
"Qatar demands from the government of Bahrain to immediately release its two nationals, preserve their rights and ensure their safety," he added.
Qatar has accused Bahrain of torturing al-Baker and said the trial "sets a dangerous precedent in Gulf ties". Bahrain denies the allegations.

The case has raised tensions between Bahrain and Qatar, already at odds because of a territorial dispute over a cluster of small islands and sandbanks in the Gulf controlled by Bahrain since the 1930s but also claimed by Qatar.
Qatar has taken the case to the International Court of Justice in The Hague. The move has angered Bahrain, which prefers a regional solution.
The dispute prompted Bahrain to boycott a two-day summit of leaders of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) which ended in the Qatari capital Doha on December 9.
The GCC, a political and economic alliance, also groups Oman, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait.
